is a very hygroscopic salt, but it leads to higher stability
against environmental moisture when introduced in our
One of the causes of perovskite degradation is attributed to
deﬁciency not only in I/Pb stoichiometry as reported for
but also for other iodide-based perovskites.
this process, moisture is essential, and the degradation is
accelerated under various stresses, such as oxygen presence,
light illumination, or applied bias. This degradation starts with
uncontrolled incorporation of moisture during the fabrication,
and for this reason, it is advisable to fabricate devices in low
humidity environment. The use of a reducing agent to prevent
formation was shown by Zhang et al. using hypophos-
agent compared to HPA and reacts with the I
solution during fabrication reducing defects in the stoichiom-
etry and leading to a more stable perovskite. The reduced
defect density is also reﬂected in the enhanced PL shown later
The stability of thin ﬁlms is monitored by comparing UV
vis absorption spectra and XRD patterns of freshly made and
aged ﬁlms. The aged ones were measured after 14 days of
storage in a Petri dish under ambient conditions of our
chemical laboratory where the ambient temperature is (21.0
C and the relative humidity (% RH) is 40
material starts to degrade within the ﬁrst week showing a
complete light yellow color after 30 days (PbI
degradation is conﬁrmed by the enhancement of the PbI
increase of the diﬀraction feature related to the (001) plane of
). The XRD pattern related to the aged
pristine material also shows broader peaks and the presence of
new diﬀraction peaks due to the reduced crystallinity and less
containing Zn(II) shows the same XRD pattern as the freshly
made and a slight reduction in crystallinity, visible by the
widening of the fwhm diﬀraction peak, which is presumably
due to the interaction of the perovskite layer (not
signiﬁcant changes compared to the freshly made ﬁlm.
Combining these results with the visual degradation of thin
incorporation stabilizes our perovskite against environmental
A major challenge in the perovskite ﬁeld is to obtain
uniform, continuous, and reproducible ﬁlms by spin-coating
deposition with the use of antisolvents. A large number of
pinholes are generated during the ﬁlm formation, and long
optimization processes dependent on substrates, precursor
solutions, and deposition conditions are necessary before
obtaining appreciable results. In recent years, many works were
focused on ﬁnding tricks to circumvent this issue, and most of
stability improvement, our thin ﬁlms suﬀer of pinholes and
inhomogeneity as shown in the SEM image in
(a) XRD patterns of freshly made and aged pristine perovskite containing Zn(II). Inset, photographs of the fresh and aged sample are
vis absorption spectrum of the freshly made and aged pristine perovskite containing Zn(II).
